Description: Body sherd (mended from three fragments) of Clazomenian black- figured pottery neck-amphora; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of three female figures (part of three long chitons decorated with short crosses in added white), to left.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Aphrodite (Naukratis), Context Φ11 or Φ14
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The sherd belongs to the same vase as Oxford AN1896-1908-G.129.1a, AN1896-1908-G.129.1c, AN1896-1908-G.129.1e and AN1896-1908-G.129.11. Cook explains that the coarse execution of the decoration on this vase is very unusual in Clazomenian black figure. The fabric of AN1896-1908-G.129.1a was analysed by the Research Laboratory for Archaeology at Oxford. Using Ward's Method Cluster Analysis (WMCA) and Principal Components Analysis (PCA), the fabric found great similarities with the fabric from Wild Goat Style sherds found at Bayrakli in Asia Minor, which Dupont had attributed production to Clazomenae. Based on the similar composition types, Dupont then suggested that the place of production for this sherd ought to be situated near Clazomenae, Erythrae, or Teos (Boardman 1986, 664).
Marked N T 14, joining a sherd marked N t 11 or N Φ 11 (also marked with an additional T. Possibly reference to Aphrodite contexts numbers 11and 14.
Bibliographic references: Cook 1952 / A List of Clazomenian Pottery (p. 125, no 17)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 87, pl. X, no. 12c)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GH.003) (Phase 1)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
Acquisition notes: The sherd was given to the Ashmolean Museum by exchange from the Trustees of the British Museum.
